text.p: The following are leading domestic stories in Portuguese newspapers.
- Popular Party leader Manuel Monteiro irritated by talks between ruling Socialist Party and opposition Social Democratic Party over revision of constitution.
- The government earned 750 million escudos in fines applied against companies which broke laws relating to working hours, according to a government report made available to the paper.
- Banco Finantia seeking to expand in Brazil.
- Average wage increases expected to be around 3.8 percent in Portugal in 1997, according to a study by private consultancy Selgec Gestao made available to the paper.
- State airline TAP-Air Portugal, which is undergoing a restructuring, negotiated the layoffs of more than 1,000 employees in 1996, well above its target of 288 layoffs.
- Banco Internacional de Credito posted a net profit of 2.5 billion escudos in 1996, up from 1.316 billion in 1995, a source in parent company Grupo Espirito Santo told the paper.
